The surest sign of regime change is when they start attacking the statues .
Americans appreciate it as much as anyone else – hence the carefully staged fall of Saddam Hussein in Firdos Square in Baghdad in 2003 .

Stephen Miller , one of the Trump regime ’ s key ideologues , knew what he did when he took a symbolic axe in a heated dispute with CNN Acosta about the president ’ s proposals to drastically limit legal immigration with the statue of liberty .
To remain fair , Miller did not attack the statue itself .
A Horde of boat owners and liberty-imitators would have merged him if he had done so .
But he attacked its significance , and especially the importance attributed to it when Emma Lazarus 's famous poem was added to its base in 1903 , 17 years after the completion of the monument .
When Miller Acosta shouted , " I do not want to go into a complete thing about history , but the statue of freedom is ... a symbol of American freedom that illuminates the world .
The poem you refer to , which was added later and is not part of the original statue of freedom ' .
Miller is correct , but , as he himself put it , it is not really about history .

It is about contemporary resonance to the crippling words of Lazarus , the only one in which a state invites not only some old immigrants , but the poorest of the poor : ' Your efforts , your poor , / your afflicted masses who yearn to breathe freely , / the miserable waste of your rich coasts . '
There was never a time when the ' miserable waste ' on our screens .
Miller did not engage in literary criticism - he made it clear that these people are not welcome in Trump ’ s US .
This conflict because of the importance of statue is part of a broader political and cultural confrontation : it is indeed a conflict over America ’ s significance .
Lazarus - and her friends who worked to place their words at the base after their death - knew very well that they were doing a highly political act .
The sculpture was intended to show the links between French and American republicanism by depicting the female embodiment of freedom in a disused classical visual representation .
Lazarus changed this meaning : In her poem , the female figure is no longer abstract - she received a voice .
And she gives herself a very different name : the mother of exiles .
The poem ’ s connection with the picture is a brilliant feminist coup and a devastating attack on American nativism .
And just as Lazarus changed the meaning of the statue , the people on the right wanted to change this for a long time .

The great shrewd Rush Limbaugh , a kind of John the Baptist for Trump ’ s coming , argued in 2010 that the statue of liberty does not invite anyone , but rather an early neo-conservatives that brings the American flame into the surrounding world : " Lady Liberty is progressing .
It is supposed to carry the torch of freedom from the United States to the rest of the world .
The torch should not shed the way to the United States . '
Almost unusual , Limbaugh encountered something here .
The importance of statue is entirely a question of the position of perception .
The great imaginative act of Lazarus was to see them as seen by the exhausted , miserable but hopeful people after long and often dreadful trips on the decks of ships .
It is really about seeing the world from the perspective of people seeking refuge and an opportunity to improve their lives .
Their statue speaks to them the words of hope and welcome they must hear .
And , of course , that is not the prospect that Miller and Trump ever want to recognize .
Their torch is not intended to illuminate the way , but to spark hatred which is their only source of power .

When Bardina Degei cooks dinner , she does not use a cook .
It rarely uses a pot .

In her wooden house in Enarotali , the capital of the Paniai reign in the restless Indonesian province of Papua , the housewife usually puts a sweet potato - locally called " nota " - directly into the fireplace .
After half an hour , the coated bones will be taken out and wrapped with icy , unwashed hands .
Degei sits on the Lehmboden - she has no furniture - where she also carries out her daily work , for example to wash clothes with water from the nearby swamp .
A bucket in a rootless space serves as a latrine .
As the youngest of her husband 's four wives , she was not assigned any fields .
Polygamy is common here .
Of course , to work late can be dangerous : most villagers are unemployed , and many drink hard , and there are soldiers here .
No one dares to walk around the village after 5 p.m.  she says .

It is a rare glimpse of daily life in the highlands of Papua , a former Dutch colony , adopted after a controversial referendum in Indonesia in 1969 , when only 1,026 elders were to vote by a public handsurvey .

An existing movement that promoted independence against Dutch rule quickly turned against the Jakarta government , which maintains control of the region and excluding foreign journalists or legal observers .
In 2003 , the province was officially divided into Papua and West Papua , with the independent part of Papua New Guinea encompassing the eastern part of the island .
Enarotali is as remote as it is , with a  90 minutes flight from in Ja, and then a 5-hour . .
There is no public transport .
The city of about 19,000 inhabitants consists of wooden houses surrounded by bamboo fences and corrugated roof , converted into various yellow brown tones .
Very few Indonesians have made their trip here , let alone journalists and virtually no foreigners .
Before Christian missionaries arrived , Mee Pago Papuans honored a God called Uga Tamee .
There have been other changes .
We were not accustomed to wearing these clothes ,  says Degei and indicates her lively , hand-woven turban , her dark shirt and light rock .
'Earlier we only had leaves on our bodies ' .
Papua is Indonesia ’ s poorest province , where 28 % of people live below the poverty line and have some of the worst child mortality and literacy rates in Asia .
But it is also Indonesia ’ s gold country .
The largest and most profitable gold mine in the world , Grasberg , owned by Phoenix Freeport McMoran , is only 60 miles from Paniai , a highland province of New Jersey with 153,000 inhabitants .
In 2015 alone , Freeport dismantled $ 3.1 billion worth of gold and copper .
Moreover , Papua has an estimated $ 78 billion of timber resources .
But these riches are a source of misery for the Papua , which ensure that Indonesia ’ s powerful military maintains a suffocating presence .
A 2005 study in the New York Times reported that Freeport paid local military and units almost $ 20 million from 1998 to 2004 , including up to $ 150,000 to a single officer .
Papuan demands for greater autonomy threaten this golden goo and are treated mercilessly .
According to activists , more than 500,000 Papua have been killed , and thousands have been raped , tortured and imprisoned by the Indonesian military since 1969 .
Mass killings in Papua ’ s tribal chiefs in the 1970 ’ s became genocide , according to the Asian Human Rights Commission .
In the region alone , the Indonesian police arrested more than 3,900 peaceful demonstrators last year .

A 2016 report by the Archdiocese Brisbane , which contains reports of previous year 's atrocities , such as illegal executions and torture - rape and electric strikes are particularly popular after another report - and the brutal suppression of peaceful demonstrations .
It is difficult to count the number of victims because incidents happen every week ,  says Andreas Harsono , Indonesian researcher for Human Rights Watch .
The screws have increased as Papua 's resources bring an influx of settlers from other parts of Indonesia .
The population of 3.5 million is 83 % Christian , but demographic development is changing as Muslim economic migrants come from the populous islands of Java , Borneo , Sumatra , and Sulawesi .
